Tangram

◢

    Highlights

    Tangram is a map renderer designed to grant you ludicrous levels of control over your map design. By drawing vector tiles live in a web browser, it allows real-time map design, display, and interactivity.

    Using WebGL, Tangram saddles and rides your graphics card into a new world of cartographic exploration. Animated shaders, 3D buildings, and dynamic filtering can be combined to produce effects normally seen only in science fiction.

    Map styles, data filters, labels, and even graphics card code can be defined in a human-readable and -writable plaintext scene file, and a JavaScript API permits direct interactive control of the style.

    Examples

    Day/Night

    Real-time design

    Because Tangram draws maps live in your browser, you can update styling properties in real-time, instantly. But changing the color is just the beginning—as every Tangram map is a 3D scene, you also have control over lights and cameras.

    In this example, an isometric camera’s perspective is varied along with the color and direction of a light, resulting in a time-lapse drone’s-eye view.

    Check out the full demo—then check out the styling code!

    Highways

    Real-time filtering, sorting, and styling

    Tangram is designed to use vector data sources such as Mapzen’s Vector Tile Service, which is a tiled, hosted version of the OpenStreetMap database. Besides points and lines, these data sources contain metadata, which Tangram can use to filter the data and change drawing styles live on stage.

    This example, inspired by Stamen’s High Road demo, sorts and styles roads based on a variety of OSM tags, including “layer”, “tunnel”, and “link” for on- and off-ramps.

    Check out the full demo—then check out the code!

    Crosshatch

    Real-time shaders

    All of these effects are possible thanks to WebGL, which is a browser-based mainline straight to your graphics card. Using Tangram’s plain-text markup language, you can write graphics card programs (called “shaders”) and even straight-up JavaScript to add interactivity, mix datasources, and control the design of your maps.

    This example uses a shader to color geometry with hand-drawn textures, blending between them based on the color, angle, and amount of light on each face.

    Check out the full demo—then check out the code!

    Tron

    Mathematical!

    This map uses procedural shaders to create a view of the future, circa 1982. The shaders, defined by mathematical functions, are applied to various data layers with UV maps, just like texturing an object in a 3D application like Blender.

    Check out the full demo—then check out the code!

    Traditional

    Cartographical!

    Making a beautiful, useful, traditionally-styled map is really difficult! Map-making is a fascinating blend of art and science, encompassing graphic design, typography, math, history, space, time, and life itself. Our ultimate goal is to make it easier to connect your knowledge, skills, and imagination to your maps. We can’t wait to hear from professional designers and cartographers, so we can continue to improve Tangram’s capabilities.

    Check out the full demo—then check out the code!

    Get Started

    Let’s Do This

    Here’s a simple demo (repo here) with a very basic example of a Tangram setup. You can learn how to modify this demo by following a tutorial.
